reviews.review_text: The blender feels nice and solid.  It is also very quiet.Tested it by making some sofrito.  While it managed to blend the vegetables (green pepper, onion, cilantro, tomatoes and garlic), it did feel a bit under powered.We had an older hand blender from Braun before and that one had a lid for the mixing cup.  This new one does not which is disappointing.Overall a good blender.

Very disappointed, previously had a braun hand blender and it lasted years it was great. The previous one was a type of plastic, so it was very light and easy to travel with. This one is made of steel so it's very heavy, and for about 45 seconds it worked brilliantly, and it's currently being picked up by DHL to return. Very disappointed.
The mechanism that connects the blender and the arm shredded… like screws being stripped.I have an older immersion blender from Cuisanart that’s lasted much longer.

When the Braun 7035 went on sale, I grabbed it. I’ve been wanting an immersion blender for years and I decided that this would be the year to get oneafter a big kitchen remodel. I received it today but when I opened the box I found that I had received a 7035X - Multi Quick 7. Or at least that’s what the box it’s in says. The box looked like it had been opened and then re-taped shut. However, examining all the pieces, non of them look used and they are all in their plastic bags.If you look at the back of the box, it shows the 5 pieces I was expecting from the description of the 7035. But in the manual, which also looked like it had been handled quite a bit, it shows an additional black attachment which turns out to be a potato masher, something I’ll never use, and several extra cutting blades for the chopping jar which only came with one blade. Since I have a mini food processor and a regular food processor I would probably not need anything more than the blade that comes with the cup so I’m okay with that too. In fact, the reason I bought this is to use for soups when you need to blend some or all of it, so that I don’t have a hot mess of putting the soup in stages, into my blender to make it creamier. I might try the whipping attachment for making meringues though. We’ll see.I did plug in the blender and attached it to all the pieces and affirmed that they all work and that I can change the speed of the blending by how hard I press the button, so everything works. I’ll find out how well it creams the butternut apple soup I  plan to make tomorrow as I will be breaking up the squash and apple pieces that have cooked for some time.I have a friend who has a Braun immersion blender that she bought 25 years ago and it’s still going strong. And Wirecutter just moved the 7035 to its top spot recommendation for immersion blenders. I’m going to keep the box it came in and the box it was shipped in because I have until Jan 25 to return it if anything goes wrong. I’m okay about not having a potato masher (I like mashing my potatoes by hand with my hand masher, or, we buy the already mashed Yukon gold potatoes at Sam’s Club as they’re tasty and easy to just heat up). And again, I’m fine about not having a bunch of blades for chopping. When I have actually used it a few times this holiday season and cold weather so soup season, I’ll edit my review. The box might be used or had just been poorly handled but the equipment inside looks new. Manual looks used though. It’s so confusing!

I've used this unit 6 times since purchasing it and I really love it. It's easy to handle and works as expected. I haven't used the attachments yet, so I can't comment on them.Given that it's a Braun, it should last.
Item arrived with internal parts loose in the box. Cannot recommend this item. I recognize this piece as a retaining clip. Inspect your unit carefully so the blade doesn’t fly off and cause injury.
Fantastic blender. Easy to use. Easy to clean. A must have!
